entry.title: Re: Create delivery with future stock
entry.content:
Hello @KC18 

Deliveries in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud are made only from in-stock items. Even if aATP/Backorder Processing has confirmed future deliveries, the system always checks the current physical stock when creating a delivery.

You can use ATP/BOP for planning purposes, but the actual delivery document can only be generated once the goods are officially posted into inventory.

For SAP documentation references, there are three key features and KBAs, Product Availability Check for Deliveries considering stock and deliveries (not planned receipts), Backorder Processing (BOP) and Advanced ATP (aATP).

SAP Help-Product Availability Check (PAC)

SAP Help – Backorder Processing (BOP)

KBA:3193069 - Advanced ATP on SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: all Knowledge Resources and Central How-to KBA

KBA:3381688 - FAQ: Alternative-based Confirmation (ABC) with aATP - S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Calculation View slower than aDSO sceanrio
entry.content: Your instinct to use a Calculation View for a virtual join is correct. The mistake was replacing the source instead of augmenting it. Use the Composite Provider to join the aDSO (for facts) to the Calculation View (for additional attributes). This is the architecture designed to give you both the flexibility of virtual joins and the performance of native BW integration.

entry.title: Using ISU_FINDER search in SAP Service Cloud Version 2 Utilities Add-on
entry.content:
Table of Contents

  • The ISU Finder
  • Structure of the blog
  • Creating a view for the search
  • Finding the data
  • Logic for Navigation
  • Conclusion
  • Appendix

 

Introduction

As of now, the standard search in SAP Service Cloud Version 2 will only look for data and objects that are stored in the SAP Service Cloud Version 2 database. For utilities, many of the attributes exist only in S/4HANA Utilities, and this blog describes how to enable a search from SAP Service Cloud Version 2 to identify the Premise based on utility attributes that only exist in S/4HANA .

We have had a utility-specific search module, ISU_FINDER, in S/4HANA for many years. As part of the utilities add-on, there is now a V2 API and a related Integration Flow that calls this search functionality in S/4HANA

This blog will show how to use this new SAP Service Cloud Version 2 API and create a mashup utilizing this search to identify Premises. In addition, I will show how to navigate from the search result list to the Premise Object.

 

The ISU Finder

The ISU_FINDER refers to a function module in S/4 with a similar name – 'ISU_FINDER'. The output from the ISU_FINDER is the ID of the object being searched for. Some of the objects supported is Business Partner, Contract Account and Premise.

The strength of this search is that it is possible to identify the above object based on a variety of utility specific attributes from meter number, invoice number among others. In the appendix I have listed the attributes I have identified to be available. I have only tested a few of them, so please verify that the attributes names are correct and that they exist.

For a use case like here, additional data is needed for the found object, not just the ID. Therefore, one or more additional calls to other API’s are required to gather the details needed. For the example used here we will execute such a second call to get the Premise Address and the Connection object id and display this on the result list.

Before diving into this specific example. There is a wealth of variations possible for utilizing this feature to find data and display data. Please do not confine yourself to the example provided here. Hope fully you can use this a way to get started on creating something that works for your specific use case.

 

Structure of the blog

The build is divided into 3 parts:

  1. Creating a view for the search
  2. Calling the ISU_FINDER and secondary calls for details
  3. Create logic for navigation within SAP Service Cloud Version 2

After the above, the mashup would need to get added to SAP Service Cloud Version 2. I have not covered this here, as I already have another blog about adding a mashup to SAP Service Cloud Version 2.

The tools used are HTML, JavaScript and CSS. I have added the complete code for this example in appendix in case someone wanted to have a look or copy certain things. The attached code is done to demo the idea and not written as a production-ready code.

For the search to work, the related integration flow should be deployed:  Get Utilities Object IDs. This integration flow is delivered in the Premise Integration Package, here is a link to the package :

Integration Flow | SAP Service Cloud V2 for Utilities Premise Integration with SAP S/4HANA | SAP Business Accelerator Hub

 

Creating a view for the search

The ISU_FINDER enables a lot of fields for search, for the example here we will use the following attributes to search by:

  • Meter number
  • POD

 

On the result screen the target is to show the following 3 fields:

  • Premise ID (enabled for navigation)
  • Premise Address
  • Connection Object ID

 

The final HTML Page will look like this:

 

 

In the appendix you can find the HTML and CSS code that will generate this view.

 

Finding the data

It is a two-step process:

  1. We will get a one or more Premise Id’s back from the ISU_FINDER search API.
  2. For each of the Premise ID’s look for further details.

The object we are looking for:

  • objectType eq PREMISES

It is only possible to retrieve the id for one object at a time.

 The query parameter we want to search by, where xxxx would be the meter number and yyyy would be the POD Id.:

  • serialNo eq xxxx
  • podId eq yyyy

 

The complete string:

‘https://{INSERT TENANT NAME}/sap/c4c/api/v1/utilities-common-integration-service/utilitiesSearch?$filter=objectType eq PREMISES and podId eq yyyy  and serialNo eq xxxx’

To test this, you can use a tool like Bruno. The only additional this is to add authentication to the call. For the tests done here, I am using Basic Authentication.

 

The result from the call will be an array listing the object type and the object ID:

 

 

For the above one Premise ID is returned.

Below is an example where the search returns multiple IDs because a wild card (*) is used for the search.

 

 

A comment on performance. Wildcard searches are supported for the ISU_FINDER. Keep in mind that using such searches without considering how many records the finder would try to retrieve could result in a very poor performance and in a bad experience for the user.

 

The second call is then to get details for Premises. Here we have an API available in SAP Service Cloud Version 2:

‘premise-service/premise?$filter=externalReferenceId eq US00002815’

This call will return the below:

 

  • Data to be displayed on the result list
  • Data to be displayed on the result list
  • This internal Id is used for the navigation from the result list to the Premise detailed view.

For every Premise ID we will make a call to retrieve the above information.

All the logic to find the information is done here using JavaScript, the code used can be found in the appendix.

 

Logic for navigation

Navigation to an object in SAP Service Cloud Version 2 is simply a call to the ‘ window.parent.postMessage’ method. The three key attributes that is required to be used in the method are:

  • Object ID, this is the internal SAP Service Cloud Version 2 object ID (C) from the image shown earlier.
  • Object type, for our example this is Premise
  • View type, here we use the detailed view.

Here are the few lines needed to trigger the navigation:

 

In the above, the ‘objectKey[0]’ is the variable holding the internal SAP Service Cloud is for Premise – this was the variable labeled (C) in the image above for the payload.

Here is a link to the help documentation for navigation: Initiate Navigation from Mashups | SAP Help Portal.

 

Conclusion

In conclusion, integrating SAP Service Cloud Version 2 with S/4HANA Utilities using the new API and ISU_FINDER functionality significantly enhances search capabilities, enabling users to locate premises based on various utility-specific attributes.

By following the steps outlined in this blog to create a search view, fetch data, and implement navigation logic, you can streamline processes and improve overall user experience. This integration opens up a wealth of possibilities for utilities to leverage their data more effectively across different SAP platforms.

 

 

APPENDIX

 

  • Attributes available for the Search
  • HTML Code
  • CSS Code
  • JavaScript Code

Attributes available for the Search

As mentioned above it is possible to identify objects by a lot of attributes. Below is an extraction from the mapping done in the Integration Flow. I have added this because the naming in the XML is closer to actual words and easier to understand.

There is a final mapping done in S/4HANA  from the XML name to the attribute naming on the actual ISU_FINDER function module. For this exercise, that last part is not so relevant and not included here.

A note of caution – I have tried to make sure the list below is accurate, but please validate before assuming the parameter works as intended.

Attributes used for the ISU_FINDER API:

HTML Code

Below is a copy of the HTML code used for this example - name of the file 'index.html'.

 

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8" />
  <title>Multi-Field Search</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" />
</head>
<body>
  <h1>Utility Search</h1>

  <div id="search-form">
    <input type="text" id="meter" placeholder="Meter number" width="15" />
    <input type="text" id="podId" placeholder="POD Id" />
    <button id="search-btn">Search</button>
    <button id="reset-btn" type="button">Reset</button>
   </div>
  
  <div class="container-unique">
    <h1>Result List</h1>
    <h1 id="dynamicHeading"></h1>
  </div> 
<div class="progress-container">
    <div id="progress-bar" class="progress-bar">0%</div>
</div>
  <table id="results-table" border="1" cellpadding="8" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%;">
    <thead>
      <tr>
        <th>Premise ID</th>
        <th>Premise Address</th>
        <th>Connection Object ID</th>
      </tr>
    </thead>
    <tbody>
      <!-- Results will go here -->
    </tbody>
  </table>


  <script src="main_7_odata.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

 

 

CSS Code

Name of this file - 'style.css'.

 

body {
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
  padding: 20px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  
}

#search-form {
  display: flex;
  flex-wrap: wrap;
  gap: 10px;
  margin-bottom: 20px;
}

#search-btn, #reset-btn {
  padding: 5px 15px;
  cursor: pointer;
  border: 1px solid #ccc;
  background-color: white;
}

#reset-btn {
  background-color: #f0f0f0;
}

#reset-btn:hover {
  background-color: #e0e0e0;
}

#results-table {
  width: 100%;
  border-collapse: collapse;
  margin-top: 10px;
}

#results-table th,
#results-table td {
  border: 1px solid #ccc;
  padding: 8px;
  text-align: left;
}

#results-table th {
  background-color: #f9f9f9;
}


.hidden {
  display: none;
}


.clickable-row {
  cursor: pointer;
}

.clickable-row:hover {
  background-color: #ddd;
}

 .container {
            display: flex;
            align-items: center;
        }

  

   .container-unique {
            font-size: 0; /* Remove whitespace between inline-block elements */
        }

        .container-unique h1,
        .container-unique h2 {
            display: inline-block;
            vertical-align: middle; /* Vertically align to the middle */
            margin: 0; /* Remove default margin */
            padding: 0 10px; /* Add some horizontal padding for spacing */
            font-size: 30px; /* Reset the font size */
        }

      .progress-container {
            width: 100%;
            background-color: #f3f3f3;
            border-radius: 25px;
        }

        .progress-bar {
            width: 0;
            height: 30px;
            background-color: #4caf50;
            text-align: center;
            line-height: 30px;
            color: white;
            border-radius: 25px;
        }

        .controls {
            margin-top: 20px;
        }

#dynamicHeading {
            
            color: blue;
        }

 

 

JavaScript Code

Name of the file - 'main_7_odata.js'.

NEED TO UPDATED:

  • Tenant id should be changed to your tenant is
  • User and Password should be updated
    • I small comment here. The user used here has to be a 'regular' admin user and not an API user. This might change in the future, but for now the second call to get the Premise details do NOT work with an API user.

 

// Global variables
const firstnameInput = document.getElementById('first_name');
const lastnameInput = document.getElementById('category');
const podInput = document.getElementById('podId');
const meterInput = document.getElementById('meter');
const invnumbInput = document.getElementById('location');

const searchBtn = document.getElementById('search-btn');
const resetBtn = document.getElementById('reset-btn');

const resultsTableBody = document.querySelector('#results-table tbody');

// API config - replace with your actual endpoint and credentials
const API_BASE = 'https://{tenant id}/sap/c4c/api/v1'
const API_FIND_ENT = 'utilities-common-integration-service/utilitiesSearch'
const API_PREM_ENT = 'premise-service/premise'

const API_USERNAME = 'xxxxxxxxxxx';
const API_PASSWORD = 'xxxxxxxxxxx';

let premDetails = [];
let tableLoaded = 'false';
let filter = '';

// First Call is to IS-U FINDER to get the list of premises
// Second call is the V2 to find details for premises

async function isuFinder(meter, search_filter) {

  console.log('Filter transferred: ', search_filter)
// Construct the full URL
const filter1 = "objectType eq PREMISES";
const filter2 = `serialNo eq ${meter}`;
const final_filter = `$filter=${filter1} and ${search_filter}`;

// Combine the filters with 'and'
  const filter = `$filter=${filter1} and ${filter2}`;
  
//  const filter = "$filter=objectType eq PREMISES";
  const url = `${API_BASE}/${API_FIND_ENT}?${final_filter}`
  
  try {
    const response = await fetch(url, {
    method: 'GET',
    headers: {
        'Authorization': 'Basic ' + btoa(API_USERNAME + ":" + API_PASSWORD),
        'Content-Type': 'application/json',
        'Accept': 'application/json'
    }
})
    prem_json = await response.json()  // need await since this is an async process
   
    try { prem_list = prem_json.value[0].results}  // test if something is returned
    catch (error) { // executed if nothing is returned
           prem_list = [];
           const headingElement = document.getElementById('dynamicHeading');
           const resultText = `- I found 0 Premise(s) in IS-U - sorry`;
           headingElement.innerText = resultText;
    };

    prem_count = prem_json.count  // number of results found
  
    for ( prem of prem_list) {
 
     // Logic handleing progress bar and dynamic display for number of premises found    
          increaseProgress(100/prem_count)
          const headingElement = document.getElementById('dynamicHeading');
          const resultText = `- I found ${prem_count} Premise(s) in IS-U, let me get the details for you`;
          headingElement.innerText = resultText;

          // Construct the full URL
           const filter1 = `externalReferenceId eq ${prem.objectKey}`;
           // Create filter
           const filter = `$filter=${filter1}`;
  
           const url = `${API_BASE}/${API_PREM_ENT}?${filter}`

           const response = await fetch(url, {
                   method: 'GET',
                 headers: {
                   'Authorization': 'Basic ' + btoa(API_USERNAME + ":" + API_PASSWORD),
                   'Content-Type': 'application/json',
                     'Accept': 'application/json'
    }
})

         prem_json = await response.json()

        if (prem_json.count != 0) {   // if premise not found in V2, go on.
                                      // this should only happen if replication from S/4 failed
          let prem_obj = { premid: [prem_json.value[0].externalReferenceId],
                          premobjkey: [prem_json.value[0].id],
                          prem_adr: [prem_json.value[0].formattedAddress],
                          connid: [prem_json.value[0].connObjExternalId]
                         }
     
          premDetails.push(prem_obj);

         }  // if
  

    } // for loop

  }  //  Try
  
  catch (error) {
        console.error(error);
    }
    printprem(premDetails);  // call to function that creates the table
  } // end of isuFinder function


// Creating table with content  
function printprem(data) { console.log('My data: ', data)

tableLoaded = false;

  data.forEach(item => {
      const row = document.createElement('tr');
        row.className = 'clickable-row'; 
          row.innerHTML = `
        <td>${item.premid}</td>
        <td>${item.prem_adr}</td>
         <td>${item.connid}</td>
        
      `;
      resultsTableBody.appendChild(row);
     
       })  // for each

  tableLoaded = 'true'   // used in below event listener logic to ensure table loaded
  attachEventListener()   // Call event listener after the table is created

}



// Adding logic to buttons in view
// Search button
searchBtn.addEventListener('click', () => {
  // clear current view
  premDetails = [];
  resultsTableBody.innerHTML = '';
  const headingElement = document.getElementById('dynamicHeading');
  const resultText = '';
  headingElement.innerText = resultText;
  decreaseProgress(100)

  // get data for search
  const meter = meterInput.value.trim();
  const podId = podInput.value.trim();
  
  // build filter for odata call
  if (meter) {filter = filter + `serialNo eq ${meter}` };
  if (podId) {filter = filter + ' and ' + `podId eq ${podId}` };

  filter_passing = filter;
  filter = '';

  isuFinder(meter, filter_passing)
}) // end of searchBtm

// Reset button
resetBtn.addEventListener('click', () => {
  // podInput.value = '';
  meterInput.value = '';
  podInput.value = '';
  // invnumbInput.value = '';
  resultsTableBody.innerHTML = '';
  premDetails = [];  // clear result list
  decreaseProgress(100)
  const headingElement = document.getElementById('dynamicHeading');
  const resultText = '';
  headingElement.innerText = resultText;

});


// Function to attach the event listener
// Triggered after the table is created
    function attachEventListener() {
        if (tableLoaded) {
            const table = document.getElementById('results-table');
            if (table) {
                table.addEventListener('click', function(event) {
                    if (event.target.tagName === 'TD') {
                        const row = event.target.parentElement;
                        const rowData = row.querySelectorAll('td');

                        // Extract data from row in table
                        const premObjKey = premDetails.find(line => line.premid = rowData[0]);
                        objectKey = premObjKey.premobjkey
                        // Call navigation
                        prem = {operation:"navigation", params: {objectKey: objectKey[0], 
                                                                 routingKey: "premise", viewType:"details"}};
                        window.parent.postMessage(prem, '*');
    
                    }
                });
            }
        }
    }      // attachEventListener

//  Functions for progress Bar
 function updateProgress(percentage) {
        const progressBar = document.getElementById('progress-bar');
        percentage = Math.max(0, Math.min(100, percentage)); // Ensure percentage is between 0 and 100
        progressBar.style.width = percentage + '%';
        progressBar.innerText = percentage.toFixed(0) + '%';
    }

 function increaseProgress(amount) {
        let currentWidth = parseFloat(document.getElementById('progress-bar').style.width) || 0;
        updateProgress(currentWidth + amount);
    }
 
 function decreaseProgress(amount) {
        let currentWidth = parseFloat(document.getElementById('progress-bar').style.width) || 0;
        updateProgress(currentWidth - amount);
    }

 function setProgress(amount) {
        updateProgress(amount);
    }

entry.title: Re: Deep Dive and Experience Sharing into SAP Joule for Developers(J4D)
entry.content:
Hi Saurabh,

Thanks for your ask. I have put the experience about SAP Build Code and SAP Build Apps in the blog. Below excerpt for a quick catch:

SAP Build Apps allow for generating pages to handle data entities and generate sample data automatically. It means, whenever you integrate any oData service/REST API/SAP BTP Destination, you get an option to automatically create the User Interface and also generate sample data.

SAP Build Code, has evolved through multiple iterations and seems it is still evolving. 

  • Created Fiori element app using Image
  • Created a series of projects with prompts
  • Created test data

I am thinking to upload videos of using the GenAI features in SAP Build Apps and SAP Build Process Automation(SBPA) in the same blog. Deliveries

For all options of the Availability Check field (except the No PAC Check option), the product availability check for a delivery only considers stock and deliveries.

Use of annotation ABAPCATALOG.VIEWENHANCEMENTCATEGORY is not allowed.
Use of annotation ANALYTICS.DATACATEGORY is not allowed.
Use of annotation ANALYTICS.DATAEXTRACTION.DELTA.CHANGEDATACAPTURE.AUTOMATIC is not allowed.

This is my CDS coding:

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'CDS-based BW extraction: table Zxxx_ABC'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: false

define view entity ZC_BW_Zxxx_ABC as select from Zxxx_ABC
{
...
}

What is my mistake? Should I ignore the warning messages?

Yvonne

entry.title: Re: Dynamically Hiding Table Columns in Print Forms with Adobe LiveCycle Designer and JavaScript
entry.content:
Hi Berti00,

Are you calling the function with onlyHideIfAllEmpty = true ?

What kind of data does the column contain/what kind if field do you use?
The condition in line 18 is responsible for checking if there's at least one cell with data (checked in a loop):

if (oField.rawValue > "")
   return false;

In my tests, this condition worked well with strings and even numbers.

You could try changing this condition or change the line after to find out where the condition is met and where not:

 

if (oField.rawValue > "")
   oField.rawValue = "not empty";

 

And add a "return false" after the loop (line 22).

Hope this helps to identify the root cause!

Best regards,
Felix

entry.title: Re: CDS view: Which annotations do I need for BW extracti...
entry.content:
Hello Yi,

Short answer: No, your code looks just fine.

What you have to do is:

  1. Click anywhere inside your CDS view
  2. Find the "Properties" tab.
  3. Go to the "API State" tab, and create a "Contract C1"

and "Release" your CDS view:

Activate it again, and all should be good 🙂 

The longer answer is pretty boring, but in essence: You have created a datasource that other people might use. So you have to promise to not break anything. 

For your small case here, set the flag, don't worry about it. Have fun 🙂

entry.title: 🚀 SAP BTP Weekly: seguridad reforzada, IA aplicada y nuevas alianzas estratégicas
entry.content:
SAP AI Core y modelos propios en BTP Las empresas ya pueden entrenar y desplegar sus propios modelos en SAP AI Core con integración nativa a datos SAP. Esto abre la puerta a IA especializada en cada industria, pero plantea un dilema: ¿cómo equilibrar innovación con compliance? Una aseguradora podría entrenar un modelo para detección de fraudes, pero ¿qué pasa si no logra explicabilidad suficiente? La promesa es grande, el riesgo también.

¿Tu organización está lista para invertir en IA propia o preferís modelos preentrenados de SAP y partners?

🔗 Más información

Nuevo release de SAP Integration Suite La suite incorpora conectores preconfigurados para Salesforce, Workday y ServiceNow, simplificando arquitecturas híbridas. El beneficio es velocidad en despliegues, pero la realidad es que muchas empresas ya tienen middleware paralelo. Un retail puede ver valor en unificar todo en BTP, pero el costo de “migrar lo viejo” nunca es trivial.

¿Vale la pena consolidar integraciones en una sola plataforma o es mejor convivir con múltiples soluciones?

🔗 Más información

DataSphere y federación en tiempo real SAP Datasphere suma capacidades para federar datos en vivo desde Snowflake y BigQuery, sin replicación masiva. Esto cambia el juego: menos ETL, más velocidad. Una minera podría consultar KPIs financieros y de producción en un único dashboard, pero la latencia y la calidad de metadatos pueden ser talón de Aquiles.

¿Creés que el futuro es federar datos en vivo o seguir apostando a replicar en un único repositorio?

🔗 Más información

Joule for Developers: IA gratis hasta 2026 El programa permite a los desarrolladores usar capacidades de IA generativa dentro de SAP Build Code, Build Apps, Process Automation y entornos ABAP sin costo hasta septiembre de 2026. Esto acelera la creación de aplicaciones, automatiza procesos y mejora la productividad, pero también plantea un reto: ¿cómo asegurar que los equipos realmente adopten la herramienta y no quede como “demo eterna”? Imaginemos un equipo de manufactura que genera código para integrarse con sensores IoT en minutos, pero sin estrategia de adopción puede terminar en pilotos aislados sin impacto real.

¿En tu empresa ya están explorando Joule for Developers o aún se percibe como una prueba de laboratorio sin plan de escalamiento?

🔗 Más información

Gestión de identidades con CIS: más allá del SSO SAP Cloud Identity Services ya no es solo un proveedor de inicio de sesión único: hoy permite aplicar MFA (autenticación multifactor), gestionar identidades externas y controlar accesos en entornos híbridos. El beneficio es claro: menos riesgos de seguridad y más trazabilidad. Pero el desafío aparece en la práctica: ¿quién define los roles y quién se hace responsable de revisarlos periódicamente? Una empresa de energía implementó MFA para usuarios críticos, pero descubrió que sin procesos de recertificación, la complejidad administrativa creció exponencialmente.

¿En tu organización la gestión de identidades es una práctica madura con roles y procesos claros, o sigue siendo una tarea reactiva que depende del equipo Basis?

🔗 Más información

Sustainability Control Tower: visibilidad ESG en tiempo real La herramienta permite consolidar métricas ambientales, sociales y de gobernanza en un solo panel conectado a SAP y fuentes externas. El valor es dar a CFOs y responsables de sostenibilidad una visión clara para reportes y decisiones estratégicas. Integrada con BTP, gana aún más potencia: puede aprovechar conectores preconfigurados, flujos de datos en tiempo real y dashboards de analítica avanzada, evitando desarrollos ad-hoc y reduciendo el time-to-value. El reto está en la calidad y consistencia de los datos: una empresa de retail logró integrar emisiones de su cadena logística, pero descubrió que sin estandarizar la captura de datos de proveedores, los reportes perdían comparabilidad.

¿Tu empresa ya mide indicadores ESG de forma integrada con SAP o todavía depende de reportes manuales y dispersos?

🔗 Más información

SAP Build Apps y citizen developers El nuevo release permite que usuarios de negocio creen apps móviles con integración directa a SAP S/4HANA. Esto democratiza la innovación, pero el riesgo es el shadow IT. Un equipo de logística puede crear su propia app de seguimiento, pero ¿qué pasa si no pasa controles de seguridad? El rol de IT pasa de desarrollador a “curador”.

¿En tu empresa los citizen developers son aliados estratégicos o una fuente de dolores de cabeza?

🔗 Más información

Agenda: SAP TechEd 2025 – primeros anuncios SAP adelantó que la próxima edición de TechEd pondrá foco en IA generativa, clean core y analítica en tiempo real. Más allá de los keynotes, lo interesante es ver cómo los anuncios aterrizan en roadmaps concretos. CIOs esperan claridad de inversión, consultores buscan nuevas certificaciones y arquitectos quieren entender las integraciones que vienen.

¿Qué esperás con más interés: casos prácticos de IA, roadmap de S/4HANA o nuevas certificaciones de BTP?

🔗 Más información

SAP BTP ofrece un valor único según el rol que lo mire. Para el CIO significa eficiencia, para el CFO transparencia y control financiero, para el arquitecto la posibilidad de diseñar integraciones más simples, para el Basis la tranquilidad de la estabilidad operativa y para el consultor la oportunidad de acelerar la entrega de valor. Sin embargo, más allá de esas perspectivas, todos enfrentamos la misma tensión: cómo lograr que la innovación se convierta en resultados tangibles sin perder el control en el proceso.

Congratulation!!
Remember you can share your badge on social media like LinkedIn, Twitter or Facebook. The badge icon can also be added to your email signature. You can also embed it into your own web page or save it locally as a PDF print version. ​

• Copying the unique URL for the digital badge for pasting into e-mails, other digital documents, or community Web sites, including expert communities such as SAP Learning Rooms

• E-mailing your digital badge to a contact or employer

• Downloading the image of your badge for use in a resume or an e-mail signature

• Downloading a printable copy of your achievement

entry.title: Re: Calculation View slower than aDSO sceanrio
entry.content: While your idea of using the generated view is creative, it introduces a layer that breaks the BW engine's optimization. The Composite Provider is not just a union tool; it's a powerful and intelligent modeling layer designed to integrate different sources before the query execution. The two-CompositeProvider approach is a "architectural smell" indicating a suboptimal design. The better, faster, and supported method is to use your single Composite Provider to unite the raw power of your aDSO with the flexible data enrichment of your custom Calculation View

entry.title: Re: Automatic generation of proforma invoice
entry.content:
To answer your question, "how can we stop it from recreating automatically", by default, SAP doesn’t track whether a proforma invoice has already been created, because proforma invoices don’t update accounting. They’re often used for customs, export, or internal documentation. So unless you build a logic to flag or exclude processed documents, the job may regenerate them.

In order to address this requirement automatically, couple of options are there

Option 1: Use Output Status or Custom Flag

  • After creating a proforma invoice, update a custom field or output status on the delivery or sales order
  • Modify the job selection logic to exclude documents with that flag

Option 2: Custom Table to Track Proforma Status

  • Create a Z-table to store delivery/sales order numbers for which proforma invoices have been created
  • Before job execution, check this table and skip already processed entries

entry.title: Re: Considerations on multiple Distribution Channels (and...
entry.content:
Yes with Option A to make it work, without blocking customer creation in real DCs, you need to:

reverse the VOR1 Mapping Logic. Instead of pointing D1 → D0, you should:

  • point D0 → D1
  • This way, materials maintained in D0 are usable in D1, but customers must exist in D1 explicitly

This flips the fallback logic:

  • Materials must be maintained in D0, usable in D1
  • Customers must be maintained in D1, not inherited from D0

entry.title: Lean Service Procurement for Project Network in SAP S/4 Hana
entry.content:
Lean Services in S/4HANA provide a lightweight, Fiori-driven approach to project service procurement, reducing overhead from large service specs while enabling fast SES creation and automated GR after approval. In this post I share a step-by-step guide that covers: configuration, WBS & activity set up, adding service components to WBS/Network, PR behavior options, PO creation, creating Lean Service Entry Sheets in Fiori, budget impact, and available tables for reporting (MMPUR_SES_HEADER, MMPUR_SES_ITEM, SGBT_NTE_CONT).

🔑Why Lean Services?

  1. Simplifies service procurement with a lightweight structure
  2. Enables faster creation of Service Entry Sheets (SES) directly in FIori apps.
  3. Integrates seamlessly with Project Systems (PS) and Materials Management (MM) for project-based external/internal services
  4. Automates Goods Receipt (GR) postings after SES approval, reducing manual work

🧩 Difference - Normal Services (Item category 'D' vs. Lean Service

AspectNormal Service (Item Category D)Lean Service Procurement
Service SpecificationRequires detailed Service Master, free-text. Often involves hierarchical service lines with limits.No need service specifications. Service items are handled like Materials- simple structure with fewer fields
Service EntryManager via ML81N (Classical)Fiori based SES with simplified UI
ReportingBased on classic service tables (ESLH, ESLL, ESKL)

Based on new Lean service tables MMPUR_SES_HEADER, MMPUR_SES_ITEM

Pre-requisite Configuration (what to set up before you start)

Step 1: Enable Procurement Mode for Project Profile

Path: SPRO > Project Systems > Structures > Operative Structures > Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) > Maintain Procurement Mode for Project Profile

This setting enables project WBS elements to create procurement items

Step 2: User Setting - Activate Service Option

In the Project builder user options (Options), make sure the service check box is enabled so the "Create -> Component -> Service" option appears. 

Step-by-Step Process

Step 1: Create Project & WBS (App: project Builder Over / CJ20N)

  1. Open Project Builder (Fiori Project Builder Overview or CJ20N)
  2. Enter Project ID and description -> create WBS elements (level 1, Level 2 as required)

Step 2: Create Activity 

  1. Right click on a WBS element -> Create -> Activity (Internal) (or External depending on business). Activities represent tasks for which services will be procured.

Step 3: Add Service as a Component

  1. Right click the Activity -> Create -> Component ->Service (this option is available only after the project procurement config and user check are set)

Step 3: Maintain Purchase Data in the Service Item

  1. Material/Service: Enter service material or free description as applicable
  2. Item category: use N (non-sock item) when using this approach
  3. Procurement: set to PF (PF = PR for WBS)

Under purchase data: enter Requirement Quantity, Purchasing Group, Price, G/L Account, Material Group, etc.

Step 4: Purchase Requisition Mode (important choice)

  1. Choose PR creation behavior for the project:
    1. Never - PR will not be auto-created (can be created later).
    2. From Release - PR created only after the project/WBS is released.
    3. Immediately - PR created when the project is saved.
  2. Save the project and then check the Purchase Data tab for the generated PR number (if PR creation mode triggers it)

Step 5: Verify Purchase Requisition

  1. Use Display Purchase Requisitions app (or ME53N) to validate PR contents (account assignment to Network/WBS, quantities, price, etc.)

Step 6: Create Purchase Order (App: Manage Purchase Orders/ME21N)

  1. Create PO using PR as reference. Fill Document Type, Supplier, Purchasing Org, Company Code, and add PR items to the PO. Check item details and post the PO.

Step 7: Create Service Entry Sheet - Lean Services (Fiori App)

  1. Open Manage Service Entry Sheets - Lean Services.
  2. Select the PO/line and open items. Fill Account Assignment Data, add any Header Note and Item text, and attach supporting documents (in attachments tab). Click create to post SES.

Header Note

Item text, and attach supporting documents (in attachments tab). Click create to post SES.

Step 8: Approval & Automatic GR

  1. After SES approval (depending on workflow), a Goods Receipt (GR) posting will be automated which updates PO history and posts financials (commitment ->actual) Check PO History tab to confirm.

Step 9: Budgeting (what to check and where)

  1. Budget report transaction: S_ALR_87013558 - run by Controlling Area + Project Definition to see Assigned / Commitment / Actual budget lines.
  2. In this case: Assigned = 500 SAR, Commitment = 400 SAR (after SES posting commitment decreased by 100), Actual = 100 SAR.

Step 10: Reporting (what to check and where)

Tables useful for reporting: MMPUR_SES_HEADER, MMPUR_SES_ITEM (SES header & item), and Notes table SGBT_NTE_COUNT (stores SES/PO notes).

(Note 1: You can build a query based on this information, or create a custom report combining MMPUR_SES_HEADER + MMPPUR_SES_ITEM tables and also the SGBT_NTE_CONT)

(Note 2: Refer SAP note: https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3503538)

Table: SGBT_NTE_CONT

Table: MMPUR_SES_HEADER

Table: MMPUR_SES_ITEM

 

If you found this guide helpful, don’t miss my other SAP MM WM blogs covering real-world automation, configuration tips, and best practices for procurement, inventory management, and warehouse management.

Click to view other SAP MM WM Blogs - SAP Community

 

Regards,

Mannem Leelamohan

entry.title: EUDR Made Simple: What Downstream Operators and Traders Really Need
entry.content:
The EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) is reshaping how companies source and trade key commodities such as cocoa, coffee, soy, palm oil, rubber, cattle, and timber. From December 2025, large companies must comply, with SMEs following by June 2026.

For first-time operators placing goods on the EU market, compliance is extensive. They must collect detailed information (Article 9), run risk assessments (Article 10), and mitigate risks (Article 11) before submitting a Due Diligence Statement (DDS). But for companies further down the chain: downstream operators and traders, the requirements are different, and often misunderstood.

Misinterpreting these obligations can lead to wasted effort. Some companies are preparing to invest in full geospatial risk analysis when all they really need is a robust system for DDS referencing. 

 Figure 1. EUDR Roles

 

What the regulation actually requires

According to EUDR and the Commission FAQ (3.4):

  • Downstream non-SME operators and non-SME traders may refer to due diligence already performed earlier in the supply chain by including the reference and verification numbers of upstream DDS.
  • Their obligations are to:
    1. Ascertain that due diligence was exercised upstream (Article 4(9)). This means collecting DDS reference and verification numbers from direct suppliers and checking they are valid in the Information System ‘TRACES’.
    2. Submit their own DDS in TRACES, referencing the upstream DDS numbers they received.
    3. Maintain a due diligence system (Article 12) to ensure they can prove upstream due diligence was exercised.

In practice, this means downstream operators and traders do not have to repeat Article 9 information gathering or Articles 10–11 risk assessment/mitigation — those obligations remain with the first operator. Their core task is DDS management: collecting, referencing, submitting, and storing.

 

The scope of work

The key challenges for downstream players are operational:

  • Collecting and validating potentially thousands of DDS reference numbers from suppliers.
  • Ensuring those numbers are valid in TRACES (the system automatically checks up to 2,000 at once).
  • Submitting their own DDS correctly, referencing the chain of upstream DDS.
  • Retaining records for at least five years for audit.

 Figure 2. TRACES connection (simulation for reference)

 

How SAP Green Token makes it simple

SAP Green Token provides exactly what downstream operators and traders need:

  • DDS collection and referencing
    Capture upstream DDS reference and verification numbers, automatically validate them in TRACES, and attach them to your own DDS.
  • Automated TRACES integration
    Submit DDS with referenced upstream numbers directly into TRACES. No re-keying, no manual uploads.
  • Centralized compliance system
    Keep DDS records, mandates, and reference chains in one secure, auditable system, ready for inspection.
  • Multi-entity support
    Manage DDS for multiple subsidiaries, commodities, or supply chains at once.
  • Audit-ready reporting
    Instantly demonstrate to authorities that you’ve ascertained upstream due diligence and correctly submitted your DDS.

 

 Figure 3. Outbound Deliveries Connected to TRACES in Green Token

 

A practical example

Consider a large EU retailer selling chocolate. The cocoa beans have already been subject to due diligence and a DDS has been filed by the importer. The retailer, as a downstream trader, does not redo due diligence on the beans. Instead, they:

  1. Collect the DDS reference numbers from their supplier.
  2. Submit their own DDS in TRACES, referencing those numbers.
  3. Store the records for five years.

With Green Token, this process is automated end-to-end, reducing administrative effort and lowering compliance risk.

Downstream operators and traders do not need full Article 10 and 11 systems. Their obligation is narrower but still critical: manage and reference DDS correctly.

SAP Green Token is designed to make this easy with automated TRACES integration, reference validation, and audit-ready records.

👉 If you’re a downstream operator or trader preparing for EUDR, focus on what really matters: robust DDS management. Learn more about SAP Green Token here.

entry.title: Re: Need to directly scrap the return stock in one -step
entry.content:
Being a new comer, please go through the below thoroughly and understand how a new discussion can be created.

Before you ask a question, please browse the community in case this question has been answered already.
If you need to create a new question, start with a descriptive title that briefly outlines what your question is about. A clear question title will help community members gain a quick initial understanding of your question. It will also help community members find your question (and its answers) when they are searching for solutions to similar problems.
When writing your question, please share what steps you took that led you to your question. If you don't, community members might tell you to take actions you've already tried yourself.
Make sure that your question is very specific. Provide as many details as you can -- such as which product version you are using and what error message you're receiving. Include screenshots if possible.

Now, coming to your post, you have not explained your requirement clearly. In order to assist in a better way, please answer the following:

  • What type of return stock are you referring to? Customer returned stock or internal return stock?
  • Where is the return stock currently located? Is it in blocked stock, quality inspection, or unrestricted use?
  • Is the stock already posted back to inventory? Or are you trying to scrap it before posting the return?
  • Are you using a specific movement type or transaction? For example, are you using MIGO, MB1A, or a custom Fiori app?
  • Do you want to scrap the stock without creating a separate return or inspection document? This helps determine if a one-step process is feasible.

entry.title: Re: 🚀 SAP BTP Weekly: seguridad reforzada, IA aplicada y nuevas alianzas estratégicas
entry.content:
La federación de datos es una herramienta muy potente cuando se gestiona adecuadamente. Pero para ello, es fundamental ser transparentes sobre cómo funciona el sistema: cómo se traduce una consulta al sistema fuente, qué funciones son compatibles con el push down, etc.

Actualmente, faltan herramientas que faciliten esta gestión. Por ejemplo, una simple combinación de funciones como LEFT o TO_VARCHAR en una consulta puede impedir que se realice el push down del filtro o cálculo. Esto puede provocar que el sistema intente traer 100 millones de filas desde BigQuery para aplicar el cálculo o filtro en Datasphere.

Y si esto ocurre cuando lo hace un diseñador, imaginemos el riesgo de dejar una tabla remota federada disponible para su uso en un dashboard. Si no existen herramientas de control, y tienen gran volúmen de datos (como suele ser el caso en BigQuery) para mi  representan un peligro si se dejan en manos de usuarios finales, y son algo a vigilar incluso cuando las utilizan usuarios técnicos.

Creo firmemente en que la federación puede ser una muy buena herramienta, de hecho hay un mercado maduro con empresas especializadas en ese mundo, y espero que se den pasos en favor de mejorarlo en la plataforma.

Saludos.

entry.title: Re: Need to directly scrap the return stock in one -step
entry.content:
There is no standard movement type or process that allows you to post customer return stock directly to scrap in one step and bypassing inventory receipt. SAP requires the return to be accounted for first, then scrapped, to ensure proper valuation, traceability, and compliance.

Could of workarounds are there which will meet your requirement.

  • Create a custom Z-transaction that posts the return with movement type 651 to blocked or QI stock. Immediately triggers a scrap posting (e.g., 551 from that same stock). This is a two-step process under the hood, but one-step for the user. You can use BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE twice in sequence with proper checks
  • The other option is Workflow automation. By this approach, keep the standard two-step process. Post return to BL or QL. Auto-trigger scrap via workflow or background job. This avoids custom movement types but still achieves automation.

If automation is the goal rather than true one-step posting, a workflow-based two-step may be safer and easier to maintain.
